cards.title: Observer Food Monthly Awards 2015 / Share your best food photography

item.title: Observer Food Monthly Awards 2015: share your best food photography
item.trailText: Share your best food pictures with GuardianWitness. The winner will be published in Observer Food Monthly
item.standFirst: Share your best food pictures with GuardianWitness. The winner will be published in Observer Food Monthly
item.body:
Observer Food Monthly would like to see your finest food photos. Whether you‚Äôre snapping street food, a home-cooked meal or a Michelin-starred restaurant we want you to share your best work with us.

You can share your photos ‚Äì one image per person please ‚Äì by clicking on the blue ‚ÄúContribute‚Äù button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the new Guardian app and search for ‚ÄúGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äù

The winning image will be chosen by OFM‚Äôs judges and published in the magazine.

Closes midnight on Tuesday 30 June 2015. Don‚Äôt forget to read the competition terms and conditions below. You can read terms and conditions for submitting content to GuardianWitness here.

Best Food Photography terms and conditions

Entering the Competition

  • The OFM 2015 Food Photography competition (the ‚ÄúCompetition‚Äù) is open to UK residents aged 18 and over.
  • The Competition is not open to employees or agencies of Guardian News & Media Limited (‚ÄúGNM‚Äù or the ‚ÄúPromoter‚Äù), their group companies or family members, professional photographers, or anyone connected to the Competition.
  • Entrants into the Competition shall be deemed to have accepted these Terms and Conditions.
  • To enter the Competition you must submit one photograph of food to the Guardian by signing into Guardian Witness and clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô button on witness.theguardian.com or by downloading the GuardianWitness app and submitting your entry through this. When submitting your entry, you must follow the instructions provided (including as to file format and size). If you have any questions about how to enter or otherwise in connection with the Competition, please email us at promotions@theguardian.com with ‚ÄúOFM 2015 Food Photography competition‚Äù in the subject line.
  • Only one entry per person. Entries on behalf of another person will not be accepted and joint submissions are not allowed. You are responsible for the cost (if any) of sending your Competition entry to us. The winner shall be the named individual from which the winning entry is received.
  • GNM accepts no responsibility for entries that are lost, delayed, misdirected or incomplete or cannot be delivered or entered for any technical or other reason. Proof of delivery of the entry is not proof of receipt by GNM.
  • The Competition opens at 15:30 on Friday 17 April 2015 and closes at 23:59 on Tuesday 30 June 2015. Entries received outside this time period will not be considered. GNM reserves the right in its absolute discretion to extend the closing date where the entries received are of insufficient quality.
  • You own the copyright to your Competition entry as its author. If another person has photographed your entry, you warrant that you have received an assignment of all associated copyright to that entry from that person. The Promoter may ask to see evidence of that assignment at any time.
  • By submitting an entry to the Competition, you give GNM:
  • a. Permission for your entry to be published on GNM websites including but not limited to witness.theguardian.com and www.theguardian.com (‚ÄúGNM Websites‚Äù) and on any social media account controlled by GNM, including but not limited to Facebook and Twitter accounts (‚ÄúGNM Social Media Accounts‚Äù) , and you grant GNM a non-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide licence to use and publish your Competition entry in electronic format (including on GNM Websites and GNM Social Media Accounts) and hard copy (including in GNM publications) for purposes connected with the Competition, and to adapt the entry to enable such publication (including to crop or otherwise edit it for such purposes), and you hereby irrevocably waive, for the benefit of GNM, all moral rights in the entry to which you are entitled; and
  • b. The right to use your name and county of residence for the sole purpose of identifying you as the author of your entry and/or as a winner of the Competition.
  • Your entry must be your own work, must not be copied, must not contain any third-party materials and/or content that you do not have permission to use, must not promote any goods or services or include any trade marks (other than those belonging to the Promoter), and must not show inappropriate or dangerous behaviour, or otherwise be obscene, defamatory, distasteful, offensive, or in breach of any applicable law or regulation, or in breach of any confidentiality obligations owed by you to third parties. If we have reason to believe your entry is in breach of this paragraph 10 then we may not consider it and may disqualify it.
  • Entrants confirm that any individual whose image is featured in the Competition entry has given consent for the use of his/her image in connection with this Competition and in accordance with these Terms and Conditions. Where an individual whose image is featured in a Competition entry is aged less than 18 years the entrant confirms that the parent or guardian of that individual has given the relevant consent.
  • We may disqualify your Competition entry for the following reasons: your entry does not comply with these Terms and Conditions; you have not obtained the consents detailed in paragraph 11 above; you are not eligible to enter the Competition; or you cannot be contacted. In the event of disqualification, we may select a new winner in accordance with the selection processes outlined below.

Picking the winners

  • A panel of judges, including at least one member who is independent of GNM, will select 1 winning entry from all valid entries received in accordance with these Terms and Conditions. Full details of the judging process and the names of the judges are available on request to ellen.vester@theguardian.com.
  • When choosing the winner, the judges will consider which entry is the most original and has the most impact. We may also ask OFM and Guardian readers for comments via our website and the judges may take those views into account too.
  • The judges will select the winning entry on or before 31 July 2015. The judges‚Äô decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into.

The Prize

  • The winner‚Äôs entry will be published in the OFM Awards issue in October 2015 or (at the Promoter‚Äôs sole discretion) at a later date and in a different media. The winner will also be invited to attend the 2015 OFM Awards Ceremony which will be held on 15 October 2015 at a location in London. The Promoter accepts no responsibility for any costs associated with the prize that are not expressly included in the prize, in particular any costs associated with travelling to the OFM Awards.
  • The winner will be notified by email or phone on or after 31 July 2015 and given details of how to claim their prize. If a winner does not respond to GNM within 7 days of being notified of their win, the winner‚Äôs prize will be forfeited and GNM shall be entitled to select another winner in accordance with the process described above (and that winner will have to respond to notification of their win within 7 days or else they will also forfeit their prize). If a winner rejects their prize or the entry is invalid or in breach of these terms, the winner‚Äôs prize will be forfeited and GNM shall be entitled to select another winner.
  • The name and county of the winner, in addition to their winning entry, will be published in the OFM Awards issue in October 2015 or (at the Promoter‚Äôs sole discretion) at a later date and in a different media.
  • The prize is non-exchangeable, non-transferable and not redeemable for cash or any other prize.
  • GNM reserves the right to substitute the prize with an alternative prize of similar value in the event that the original prize offered is not available.

Some other rules

  • The winner may be required to take part in promotional activity related to the Competition and the winner shall participate in such activity on the Promoter‚Äôs reasonable request. The winner consents to the use by the Promoter and its related companies, both before and after the closing date of the Competition for an unlimited time, of the winner‚Äôs voice, image, photograph and name for publicity purposes (in any medium, including still photographs and films, and on the internet, including any websites hosted by the Promoter and its related companies) and in advertising, marketing or promotional material without additional compensation or prior notice and, in entering the Competition, all entrants consent to the same.
  • The Promoter shall use and take care of any personal information you supply to it as described in its privacy policy, a copy of which can be seen at theguardian.com/help/privacy-policy, and in accordance with data protection legislation. By entering the Competition, you agree to the collection, retention, usage and distribution of your personal information in order to process and contact you about your Competition entry, and for the purposes outlined in paragraph 18 above.
  • GNM accepts no responsibility for any damage, loss, liabilities, injury or disappointment incurred or suffered by you as a result of entering the Competition or accepting the prize. GNM further disclaims liability for any injury or damage to your or any other person‚Äôs computer relating to or resulting from participation in or downloading any materials in connection with the Competition. Nothing in these Terms and Conditions shall exclude the liability of GNM under law for fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation, or for death or personal injury resulting from its negligence.
  • GNM reserves the right at any time and from time to time to modify or discontinue, temporarily or permanently, this Competition with or without prior notice due to reasons outside its reasonable control (including, without limitation, in the case of anticipated, suspected or actual fraud). The decision of GNM in all matters relating to the Competition is final and no correspondence will be entered into.
  • GNM shall not be liable for any failure to comply with its obligations relating to this Competition where the failure is caused by something outside its reasonable control. Such circumstances shall include, but not be limited to, weather conditions, fire, flood, hurricane, strike, industrial dispute, war, hostilities, political unrest, riots, civil commotion, inevitable accidents, supervening legislation or any other circumstances amounting to force majeure.
  • The Competition and these Terms and Conditions will be governed by English law and entrants to the Competition submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English courts.
  • Promoter: Guardian News & Media Limited, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London, N1 9GU.

cards.title: Father's Day / What does being a dad mean to you?
cards.rawTitle: What does being a dad mean to you?

item.title: Father's Day: what does being a dad mean to you?
item.trailText: To celebrate Father‚Äôs Day this Sunday in the UK and US, we‚Äôd like to see your photos and experiences of fatherhood
item.standFirst: To celebrate Father‚Äôs Day this Sunday in the UK and US, we‚Äôd like to see your photos and experiences of fatherhood
item.body:
With Father‚Äôs Day coming up this Sunday 21 June, we‚Äôd like you to share your stories, videos and photographs of fatherhood. Whether you‚Äôve recently become a father for the first time, or have seen your children grow up and have families of their own, we‚Äôd like to hear your stories.

Father‚Äôs Day is also a time to remember your own fathers, so if you have a photograph or story about them, share it with us. We will feature the most interesting contributions in a Father‚Äôs Day gallery.

Some of you have already shared photographs of history repeating itself with your own children becoming fathers themselves:

Others have shared their most treasured memories of their own fathers and how they became doting grandparents:

Whether you have an experience of fatherhood or a photograph and story about your own father, you can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äô

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: International Yoga Day / Share your photos, videos and stories
cards.rawTitle: Share your photos, videos and stories

item.title: International Yoga Day: share your photos, videos and stories
item.trailText: Whether you‚Äôre a yoga enthusiast or trying it for the first time, we‚Äôd like to see your pictures and hear your experiences
item.standFirst: Whether you‚Äôre a yoga enthusiast or trying it for the first time, we‚Äôd like to see your pictures and hear your experiences
item.body:
The first International Yoga Day is set to take place on Sunday 21 June, with 35,000 people gathering in New Delhi in an attempt to break the world record for the largest yoga class. If you‚Äôre planning on celebrating the day we‚Äôd like to hear from you.

Will you be attending one of the free sessions taking place around the world, like the ones in London or Salzburg? What‚Äôs your favourite yoga pose? Whether it‚Äôs a picture of your best downward dog or you‚Äôre trying it for the first time, share your photos, videos and stories with us.

You can do this by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äô

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Restoring balance / These are nation-changing times ‚Äî help us hold power to account
cards.rawTitle: These are nation-changing times ‚Äî help us hold power to account

item.title: These are nation-changing times ‚Äî help us hold power to account
item.trailText: In a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance. Become a Guardian Member and join our community of writers and readers to debate the big issues and help us challenge the status quo
item.standFirst: In a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance. Become a Guardian Member and join our community of writers and readers to debate the big issues and help us challenge the status quo
item.body:
After the election, with five years until the next, there is more need than ever for a strong, independent voice to stand out against the prevailing winds. Ahead of us lie decisions that may change the nature of Britain irrevocably ‚Äì and it is essential that there are journalists who are asking tough questions and challenging the status quo.

With the Human Rights Act in jeopardy, the Guardian will be there exposing the myth-makers. When the home secretary herself repeats media distortions about human rights ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe illegal immigrant who cannot be deported because, and I am not making this up, he had a pet cat‚Äù ‚Äì someone needs to set the record straight: no, minister, the judge did not say the cat stopped the man‚Äôs deportation.

When severe benefit cuts fall on those least able to cope, the Guardian will make sure the impact is revealed. When the public is told that Benefits Street-type scroungers take the lion‚Äôs share, the Guardian strips the factoids from the facts: only 3% of the social security bill goes to the unemployed, while half goes to pensioners. When the bedroom tax and benefit sanctions leave families without food, the Guardian shines a light on the plight of those using food banks.

If you read the Guardian, become a Member and part of our community of writers and readers

Britain faces a monumental decision in the EU referendum. However strict the rules for the yes and no campaigns, nothing will stop the blasts from Britain‚Äôs Eurosceptic media. A wall of sound will warp the democratic process ‚Äì and the Guardian‚Äôs independent voice will matter more than ever. No press baron owns us, so we are free to think, write and report without constraint.

I doubt anyone agrees with everything we publish, and indeed we make a point of encouraging a rainbow of views from contributors. But in a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance, hold power to account, challenge the conventional view and give a voice to the voiceless.

If you read the Guardian, become a Member and part of our community of writers and readers. Stand with us at live events to get closer to the issues of these times. Bring us your stories and contribute your thoughts.

These are crucial nation-changing years so, above all, become a Member to help support fearless, independent journalism, open to all readers, with no paywall.

item.title: Catholics react to Pope Francis's encyclical on climate change
item.trailText: Following the publication of the Pope‚Äôs encyclical on climate change, Catholics share their views on Laudato Si
item.standFirst: Following the publication of the Pope‚Äôs encyclical on climate change, Catholics share their views on Laudato Si
item.body: In his encyclical on climate change, Laudato Si, Pope Francis emphasises overconsumption and the individual responsibility everyone has to our ‚Äòcommon home‚Äô. Here‚Äôs a selection of what Catholics on social media were saying.

item.title: Ramadan: share your photos and stories
item.trailText: How are you preparing for the ninth month of the Islamic calendar? Share your experiences and pictures with us
item.standFirst: How are you preparing for the ninth month of the Islamic calendar? Share your experiences and pictures with us
item.body:
Ramadan, the holiest month in the Islamic calendar, begins this evening with Muslims around the world fasting for a month from sunrise until sunset.

During Ramadan, as well as fasting many Muslims give money or volunteer for particular causes. What are you doing for Ramadan? Are you fasting, fundraising or helping the homeless? Have you set yourself a particular challenge or are you doing something different this year? We‚Äôd also like to hear from those adhering to traditions in modern or unusual surroundings, such as the Somalis marking Ramadan in a synagogue in north London.

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äô

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.
